title: White House Withdraws Nomination of Trump’s FEMA Pick
text:
Jeff Byard, associate administrator for FEMA’s Office of Response and Recovery, asked to yank his nomination to head the agency last week.

The White House withdrew its nomination of Jeffrey Byard to head the Federal Emergency Management Agency, a week after Mr. Byard asked to pull his nomination amid senators’ concerns about personal matters in his background.

President Trump late Wednesday suggested he would nominate Peter Gaynor, the agency’s acting administrator, to serve in that role in a permanent capacity. He said Mr. Byard “would have been very good, but we’re also very happy with the man who’s acting, who has been acting.”

The White House made the formal notification Thursday in a list of withdrawn nominations provided to the Senate.

Mr. Byard is currently serving as associate administrator for FEMA’s Office of Response and Recovery. In a letter to acting Homeland Security Secretary Kevin McAleenan asking to withdraw his nomination, Mr. Byard said he would continue to serve in that role. Lawmakers in recent days had acknowledged problems with Mr. Byard’s nomination, without providing details about their concerns. Sen. Ron Johnson (R., Wis.), the chairman of the Senate committee that oversees FEMA, told Politico last week: “There were some issues raised that are being investigated and that’s all I’ll say about it." A FEMA spokeswoman said Wednesday that Mr. Byard is a “well-respected emergency manager” and that the agency can’t comment on “accusations made regarding a personal matter that allegedly occurred prior to Mr. Byard’s tenure with the agency.” The agency’s last administrator, Brock Long, resigned in February after he came under fire for his unauthorized use of government vehicles.
